722820f-a.text:
Riverside Drive (thorough fare at the right upon which the buildings shown,front), north from a point on a line with West 163rd Street (extreme right) showing a more or less general view of the Washington Heights building outline on the westerly margin of Manhattan. Two groups of structures of importance are:the low buildings of the New York Institution for the Deaf (right, extending from West 163rd to 165th Streets) and the Columbia University - Presbyterian Hospital Medical Center which are just north of the aforementioned. View 2 of this set, being from a vantage point to the north, emphasises the latter. The foreground area is today (1938), included officially in Port Washington Park, that marginal garden spot under the new George
Washington Bridge (in the left background).
September 24, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722820f-b.text:
Riverside Drive (thorough fare at the right upon which the buildings shown,front), north from a point on a line with West 163rd Street (extreme right) showing a more or less general view of the Washington Heights building outline on the westerly margin of Manhattan. Two groups of structures of importance are:the low buildings of the New York Institution for the Deaf (right, extending from West 163rd to 165th Streets) and the Columbia University - Presbyterian Hospital Medical Center which are just north of the aforementioned. View 2 of this set, being from a vantage point to the north, emphasises the latter. The foreground area is today (1938), included officially in Port Washington Park, that marginal garden spot under the new George
Washington Bridge (in the left background).
September 24, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722819f-b.text:
Riverside Drive, north from W. 163rd Street. Buildings shown form the Columbia Medical Center. On the right are the main units at Broadway. The Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing is in the
center. To the left is the Neurological Institute.
View 3 is taken on that portion of the Drive, the Boulevard Lafayette and includes at its right one of the old buildinrs that formerly housed the New York Institution for the Deaf. This escarpment appeare in the midground of the preceding photos.
May 18, 1940
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

715719f-a.text:
West 163rd Street, north side, west from Riverside Drive, showing the vacated grounds of the former New York School for
the Deaf extending to Fort Washington Avenue.
May 18, 1940
P. L. Sperr
Same as above, from another angle.
P. L. Sperr  April 27, 1941

722821f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, at the N. E. corner of W. 163rd Street, showing the grounds of the New York School for the Deaf. TRese are being cleared of the former institution buildings; though one still remains. In the background are the massive units of
the Columbia Medical Center.
View 1: August 21, 1939
Views 2,3: May 18, 1940
P. L. Sperr

722823f-c.text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, east side, north from West 163rd to 165th Streets, showing the buildings and grounds of the N.Y. Institution
for the Deaf.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A limited view, showing only buildings at the N.E. corner of West 163rd Street; the southwestern corner of these extensive grounds.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A close up of building shown in No. 2.
June 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
